elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Crystal structure of <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> as a representative showing the coordination sphere of the Co cation (orange<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>metal(II), blue<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nitrogen, yellow<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>sulfur, green<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>chlorine, grey<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>carbon, white<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hydrogen). ORTEP plots of <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> can be found in <ce:cross-ref id="c0225" refid="s0115">Figs. S3 and S4 in the Supplementary material</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Crystal structure of 1-Co as a representative showing the coordination sphere of the Co cation (orange=metal(II), blue=nitrogen, yellow=sulfur, green=chlorine, grey=carbon, white=hydrogen). ORTEP plots of 1-Fe and 1-Co can be found in Figs. S3 and S4 in the Supplementary material.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Reaction of Fe(II) and Co(II) thiocyanate with 2-chloropyrazine leas to the formation of five new coordination polymers that were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Magnetic measurements shows that dependent on the crystal structure and the metal cation Curie-Weiss paramagnetism, metamagnetism or antiferromagnetism is observed.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Some new discrete complexes based on Fe(II) and Co(II) thiocyanate were prepared.   ⋅ These compounds transforms into new coordination polymers on heating.   ⋅ In these polymers the metal atom are μ-1,3-bridged by the anionic ligands.   ⋅ The iron compounds shows antiferromagnetic ordering on cooling.   ⋅ For the cobalt compound metamagnetic behavior is observed with a large critical field.

elements.clean_text:
Some new discrete complexes based on Fe(II) and Co(II) thiocyanate were prepared.

These compounds transforms into new coordination polymers on heating.

In these polymers the metal atom are μ-1,3-bridged by the anionic ligands.

The iron compounds shows antiferromagnetic ordering on cooling.

For the cobalt compound metamagnetic behavior is observed with a large critical field.

Abstract

Investigations on the synthesis of coordination compounds based on Fe(NCS)2 and Co(NCS)2 with 2-chloropyrazine as ligand leads to the formation of five new compounds. Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (1-Fe), Co(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (1-Co) and Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4⋅2-chloropyrazine solvate (2-Fe) consists of discrete complexes in which the metal cations are octahedrally coordinated and in which the thiocyanato anions are only terminal coordinated. On heating 1-Fe and 1-Co transform into new coordination polymers of composition [Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2] n  (3-Fe) and [Co(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2] n  (3-Co) which are isotypic. No access to large and phase pure amounts of these compounds was found in solution but the structure of 3-Co was determined from a crystal obtained in one batch by accident. In the crystal structure of 3-Co and 3-Fe the metal(II) cations are coordinated by two N-bonded as well as two S-bonded thiocyanato anions and two 2-chloropyrazine ligands and are linked by μ-1,3-bridging anions into layers. Magnetic measurements of 1-Fe and 1-Co show only Curie- or Curie-Weiss paramagnetism, whereas for 3-Fe antiferromagnetic ordering and for 3-Co metamagnetic behavior is observed.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Recently, investigation on a more rational preparation of coordination polymers that shows cooperative magnetic phenomena is a major field of chemical research . In this context several compounds are reported in which paramagnetic transition metal cations are linked by small-sized anionic ligands that can mediate magnetic exchange . In our own research we are interested in the synthesis of paramagnetic thio- and selenocyanato coordination polymers in which the metal cations are linked by bridging thiocyanato anions . Because of the low chalcophilicity of Mn(II), Fe(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) the synthesis of such compounds based on these metal cations is sometimes difficult to achieve and thus, we have developed an alternative approach which is based on thermal decomposition of suitable precursors compounds and which selectively lead to the formation of 1D or 2D structures . Especially coordination polymers with 1D structures based on metal cations with a large magnetic anisotropy like e.g. Co(II) and Fe(II) are of special importance because they are candidates for the occurrence of single chain magnetism (SCM) . Such compounds shows a slow relaxation of the magnetization and have some potential for future application in the area of high density storage materials . In this context we reported on the first thio- and selenocyanates that shows this rare magnetic phenomenon . In most of these compounds the metal cations are octahedrally coordinated by two monodentate N-donor ligands and four thio- or selenocyanato anions and are linked into chains by pairs of these anionic ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, investigation on a more rational preparation of coordination polymers that shows cooperative magnetic phenomena is a major field of chemical research . In this context several compounds are reported in which paramagnetic transition metal cations are linked by small-sized anionic ligands that can mediate magnetic exchange . In our own research we are interested in the synthesis of paramagnetic thio- and selenocyanato coordination polymers in which the metal cations are linked by bridging thiocyanato anions . Because of the low chalcophilicity of Mn(II), Fe(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) the synthesis of such compounds based on these metal cations is sometimes difficult to achieve and thus, we have developed an alternative approach which is based on thermal decomposition of suitable precursors compounds and which selectively lead to the formation of 1D or 2D structures . Especially coordination polymers with 1D structures based on metal cations with a large magnetic anisotropy like e.g. Co(II) and Fe(II) are of special importance because they are candidates for the occurrence of single chain magnetism (SCM) . Such compounds shows a slow relaxation of the magnetization and have some potential for future application in the area of high density storage materials . In this context we reported on the first thio- and selenocyanates that shows this rare magnetic phenomenon . In most of these compounds the metal cations are octahedrally coordinated by two monodentate N-donor ligands and four thio- or selenocyanato anions and are linked into chains by pairs of these anionic ligands ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In the course of our project we decided to study the influence of the co-ligand onto the topology of the coordination network and its magnetic properties. As neutral co-ligand 2-chloropyrazine was selected. Although 2-chloropyrazine is a bidentate ligand, it frequently is found to act as monodentate ligand because the bulky chloro atom is directly neighbored to one of the coordinating nitrogen atoms . In previous work we investigated nickel(II) thiocyanato coordination polymers with this ligands . We have found several precursors that transforms into a compound of composition Ni(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> that is a metamagnet with a critical field of 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe. Surprisingly, in contrast to all other compounds investigated by us in the last few years this compounds shows a 2D nickel thiocyanato network, in which the paramagnetic Ni(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains are linked into layers by additional anionic ligands that obviously mediate antiferromagnetic exchange of the ferromagnetically coupled chains. However, as mentioned above in the view of the actual importance of SCM behavior compounds based on Co(II) and Fe(II) thiocyanato are of much higher interest and therefore, were investigated by us. In this context the question raises if these cations will form 1D chains like shown in  that might show SCM behavior or if these cations prefer a similar coordination like Ni(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> reported recently . In this context it is mentioned that in some cases also polymorphic modifications of such thiocyanato compounds can be obtained if the synthesis is performed by thermal decomposition or by conventional solution synthesis . Here we report on our investigations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the course of our project we decided to study the influence of the co-ligand onto the topology of the coordination network and its magnetic properties. As neutral co-ligand 2-chloropyrazine was selected. Although 2-chloropyrazine is a bidentate ligand, it frequently is found to act as monodentate ligand because the bulky chloro atom is directly neighbored to one of the coordinating nitrogen atoms . In previous work we investigated nickel(II) thiocyanato coordination polymers with this ligands . We have found several precursors that transforms into a compound of composition Ni(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2 that is a metamagnet with a critical field of 14kOe. Surprisingly, in contrast to all other compounds investigated by us in the last few years this compounds shows a 2D nickel thiocyanato network, in which the paramagnetic Ni(NCS)2 chains are linked into layers by additional anionic ligands that obviously mediate antiferromagnetic exchange of the ferromagnetically coupled chains. However, as mentioned above in the view of the actual importance of SCM behavior compounds based on Co(II) and Fe(II) thiocyanato are of much higher interest and therefore, were investigated by us. In this context the question raises if these cations will form 1D chains like shown in  that might show SCM behavior or if these cations prefer a similar coordination like Ni(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2 reported recently . In this context it is mentioned that in some cases also polymorphic modifications of such thiocyanato compounds can be obtained if the synthesis is performed by thermal decomposition or by conventional solution synthesis . Here we report on our investigations.

Independent of the reaction conditions we always obtained the same crystalline phases that appeared to be isotypic. Elemental analysis leads to the composition M(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (Fe<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

<ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold>) and IR-analysis prove that only N-terminal bonded thiocyanato anions are present, which is indicated by the asymmetric stretching vibration <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(CN) which occurs at 2045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and at 2058<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> (see  and ). elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Preliminary investigations

In the beginning of our investigations different molar ratios of Co(NCS)2 or FeSO4⋅7H2O and KNCS were reacted with 2-chloropyrazine in different solvents and the products of this reactions were investigated by X-ray powder diffraction. Independent of the reaction conditions we always obtained the same crystalline phases that appeared to be isotypic. Elemental analysis leads to the composition M(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (Fe= 1-Fe, Co= 1-Co) and IR-analysis prove that only N-terminal bonded thiocyanato anions are present, which is indicated by the asymmetric stretching vibration ν as(CN) which occurs at 2045cm-1 for 1-Fe and at 2058cm-1 for 1-Co (see  and ). There are no indications for the formation of additional compounds with a lower metal to 2-chloropyrazine content. However, compounds 1-Fe and 1-Co are suitable precursor compounds that on thermal decomposition might lose part of the ligands in order to transform into 2-chloropyrazine deficient compounds in which the metal cations are linked by the thiocyanato anions. To investigated if this is the case for the present compounds 1-Fe and 1-Co were investigated for their thermal properties (see below).

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold>).</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures

Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (1-Fe) and Co(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (1-Co) are isotypic and crystallize in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     with one formula unit in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit consists of one metal(II) cation, which is located on a center of inversion and of one thiocyanato anion and two 2-chloropyrazine ligands located in general position (). In the crystal structure each metal(II) cation is coordinated by two terminal N-bonded thiocyanato anions and four N-bonded 2-chloropyrazine ligands in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry ( ). The MN6 distances are in the range of 2.032(3) to 2.268(2)Å with angles around the metal(II) cations of 88.45(8)° to 91.55(8)° and 180° ( ).

Based on the structural data X-ray powder patterns were calculated and compared the experimental patterns which proves that both compounds are obtained as single crystalline phases ().

Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4⋅2-chloropyrazine solvate 2-Fe crystallizes in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     with two formula units in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit consist of one iron(II) cation, two thiocyanato anions and four coordinating 2-chloropyrazine ligands as well as one non-coordinated 2-chloropyrazine ligand all of them located in general position (). The FeN6 octahedra is slightly distorted with distances in the range of 2.048(2) to 2.2477(18)Å and angles around the iron(II) cation of 86.59(7)° to 92.79(7)° and 177.70(8)° to 178.88(8)° ( ).

It is noted that only a few crystals of this compound were obtained in a mixture with <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and therefore no larger amounts of phase pure samples are available.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">[Co(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold>) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> with four formula units in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit consists of one cobalt(II) cation, two thiocyanato anions and two 2-chloropyrazine ligands all of them located in general positions (). It must be noted this compound is isotypic to the ligand-deficient 1:2 compound with nickel(II) reported recently . Each cobalt(II) cation is coordinated by two <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-bonded and two <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-bonded as well as two 2-chloropyrazine ligands into a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The CoN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> distances are in range of 2.041(8)–2.586(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with angles around the cobalt(II) cation of 83.6(2)° to 95.0(2)° and 172.93(10)° to 177.8(3)° (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [Co(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2] n  (3-Co) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with four formula units in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit consists of one cobalt(II) cation, two thiocyanato anions and two 2-chloropyrazine ligands all of them located in general positions (). It must be noted this compound is isotypic to the ligand-deficient 1:2 compound with nickel(II) reported recently . Each cobalt(II) cation is coordinated by two N-bonded and two S-bonded as well as two 2-chloropyrazine ligands into a slightly distorted octahedral geometry ( ). The CoN4S2 distances are in range of 2.041(8)-2.586(3)Å with angles around the cobalt(II) cation of 83.6(2)° to 95.0(2)° and 172.93(10)° to 177.8(3)° ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">In the crystal structure dimeric units are present, in which the metal cations are linked by pairs of μ-1,3-bridging thiocyanato anions whereas two units are connected by pairs of thiocyanato anions into chains (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>: top). These dimers are linked into chains by single anionic ligands, which are further connected into layers by additional thiocyanato anions (: bottom). This structural motif is common and observed in a number of similar compounds . The 2-chloropyrazine ligands only act as a monodentate ligand. As mentioned above this compound was obtained by serendipity and cannot be prepared in larger amounts as a phase pure material.</ce:para>

Moreover from all investigations presented above there is no indication that a compound of composition [Fe(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Thermoanalytical investigations

As mentioned above compound 1-Fe and 1-Co can be synthesized phase-pure in solution whereas compound 3-Co with a bridging coordination is not available directly from solution as phase pure compound and in larger amounts. Moreover from all investigations presented above there is no indication that a compound of composition [Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2] n  exists. Therefore, the precursors 1-Fe and 1-Co were investigated for their thermal properties using simultaneous DTA-TG measurements ( ). On heating two mass steps are observed in the TG curve of each compound, which are accompanied with endothermic events in the DTA curve. The experimental mass loss of Δm exp =34.6% in the first and Δm exp =34.5% in the second step for 1-Fe and Δm exp =35.7% in the first and Δm exp =34.4% in the second step for 1-Co are good agreement with the loss of two 2-chloropyrazine ligands in each step (Δm calc =-36.4% for 1-Fe and -36.2% for 1-Co). On further heating the remaining metal(II) thiocyanates decompose.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">To verify the nature of the intermediates additional TG experiments were performed and stopped after the first heating step. The residues obtained were investigated by IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis yields a composition of M(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Fe (<ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold>) and M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co (<ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold>) and IR spectroscopic investigations indicates the presence of μ-1,3-bridging thiocyanato anions, because values for <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(CN) of 2095<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold>) and 2105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold>) are observed (see ) . However, comparison of the experimental XRPD patterns of these intermediates with that calculated for <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> from single crystal data prove that both compounds are isotypic and are obtained as single crystalline phases (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). The lattice parameters for <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> were additionally determined from the X-ray powder data to give <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.7168 (5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.5022 (5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15.7235 (8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>97.407 (2)° and <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1787.8 (2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To verify the nature of the intermediates additional TG experiments were performed and stopped after the first heating step. The residues obtained were investigated by IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis yields a composition of M(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2 with M=Fe (3-Fe) and M=Co (3-Co) and IR spectroscopic investigations indicates the presence of μ-1,3-bridging thiocyanato anions, because values for ν as(CN) of 2095cm-1 (3-Fe) and 2105cm-1 (3-Co) are observed (see ) . However, comparison of the experimental XRPD patterns of these intermediates with that calculated for 3-Co from single crystal data prove that both compounds are isotypic and are obtained as single crystalline phases ( ). The lattice parameters for 3-Fe were additionally determined from the X-ray powder data to give a =10.7168 (5)Å, b =9.5022 (5)Å, c =15.7235 (8)Å, β =97.407 (2)° and V =1787.8 (2)Å3.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic investigations

To investigated the magnetic properties of compound 1-Fe, 1-Co, 3-Fe and 3-Co their temperature dependence of the susceptibility was measured applying a magnetic field of H DC =1kOe in the temperature range of 300-2K. For compounds 1-Fe and 1-Co, which consists of discrete complexes only Curie-Weiss paramagnetic behavior is observed. Fitting their magnetic data according to the Curie-Weiss law yields to a Weiss constant of θ =-0.45K for 1-Fe and θ =-4.14K for 1-Co, which are practically zero. Moreover, because of the strong spin orbit coupling of Co(II) cations these values are in any case overestimated. However, the effective magnetic moment of μ eff =5.21μB for 1-Fe and μ eff =5.11μB for 1-Co are slightly higher than the expected value of 4.89μB for Fe2+ (S =2, g =2) and 3.87μB for Co2+ (S =3/2, g =2) (  and ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Surprisingly, after the maximum the susceptibility increases again at low temperatures indicating for canted antiferromagnetism. However, from a structural point of view there are no hints for such a behavior and it is more likely that this compound is contaminated with a very small amount of a paramagnetic impurity, which is not visible in the XRPD measurements. Decomposition of this compound can be excluded because the powder pattern after the magnetic measurements is identical with that of the pristine material (). Because the TG curve is not perfectly resolved it is possible that compound <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> is contaminated with the precursor <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold>. To prove this assumption an additional batch was investigated leading to the same magnetic behavior but the ratio between the maximum and the increase at low temperatures is different, which strongly indicated that a paramagnetic impurity is present in different amounts (). Finally, for a canted antiferromagnet a small signal is present in the imaginary part (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>″) of the AC susceptibility, which is absent for a “normal” antiferromagnet and AC measurements on <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> shows no signal in <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>″ proving pure antiferromagnetic behavior.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Surprisingly, after the maximum the susceptibility increases again at low temperatures indicating for canted antiferromagnetism. However, from a structural point of view there are no hints for such a behavior and it is more likely that this compound is contaminated with a very small amount of a paramagnetic impurity, which is not visible in the XRPD measurements. Decomposition of this compound can be excluded because the powder pattern after the magnetic measurements is identical with that of the pristine material (). Because the TG curve is not perfectly resolved it is possible that compound 3-Fe is contaminated with the precursor 1-Fe. To prove this assumption an additional batch was investigated leading to the same magnetic behavior but the ratio between the maximum and the increase at low temperatures is different, which strongly indicated that a paramagnetic impurity is present in different amounts (). Finally, for a canted antiferromagnet a small signal is present in the imaginary part (χ") of the AC susceptibility, which is absent for a "normal" antiferromagnet and AC measurements on 3-Fe shows no signal in χ" proving pure antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.clean_text: Fitting the magnetic data according to the Curie-Weiss law reveal a strong negative Weiss constant of θ =-23.98K, which might be shifted to the negativer side because of strong spin-orbit coupling. The effective magnetic moment of μ eff =5.04μB obtained from the √8χ M T versus T curve at room-temperature is also slightly higher than the expected value for Co2+ (S =3/2, g =2) (: inset). The reasons for this fact are the large magnetic anisotropy of Co2+ and their spin-orbit coupling, which is frequently observed in cobalt(II) compounds. To investigated if a metamagnetic transition is present an initial curve at T =2K up 0-90kOe was measured. From the first derivative dM/dH versus H the critical field H C was determined to be 47kOe, which represents the transition point from the antiferromagnetic to the saturated paramagnetic phase (). To investigate this behavior in more detail a saturation magnetization experiment at T =2K in the range of ±90kOe was performed which shows a sigmoidal shape typical for metamagnetic behavior with practically no hysteresis and no saturation ( ).

The fact that no saturation can be reached is not uncommon and is actually observed in other compounds and can be traced back to the high anisotropy of the Co(II) cations .</ce:para>

The fact that no saturation can be reached is not uncommon and is actually observed in other compounds and can be traced back to the high anisotropy of the Co(II) cations .

<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf> was investigated, which proves that as expected <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf> decreases with increasing field. From the <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> versus <ce:italic>H</ce:italic> measurements at different temperatures the temperature dependence of the critical field was also measured. All these measurements can be combined to prepare the magnetic phase diagram in which the region below the curve corresponds to the antiferromagnetic phase while the region above the curve corresponds to the supersaturated paramagnetic phase (field-induced ferromagnetic phase) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>). This curve is typical for metamagnets with a large magnetic anisotropy .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: However, from the χ M versus T measurements at different magnetic field the temperature dependence of T N was investigated, which proves that as expected T N decreases with increasing field. From the M versus H measurements at different temperatures the temperature dependence of the critical field was also measured. All these measurements can be combined to prepare the magnetic phase diagram in which the region below the curve corresponds to the antiferromagnetic phase while the region above the curve corresponds to the supersaturated paramagnetic phase (field-induced ferromagnetic phase) ( ). This curve is typical for metamagnets with a large magnetic anisotropy .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st035">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">In the present contribution investigations on the synthesis and the magnetic properties of new coordination polymers based on iron and cobalt thiocyanato coordination compounds with 2-chloropyrazine as neutral co-ligand were presented. The motivation for this work can be traced back to previous investigations, in which 1D thiocyanato coordination polymers with monodentate co-ligands of composition M(NCX)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Fe, Co; X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>S, Se; L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>monodentate N-donor co-ligand) were prepared that shows a slow relaxation of the magnetization. The present investigations have shown that compounds of these composition cannot be prepared phase pure from solution but are accessible by thermal decomposition of suitable precursor compounds. As expected, 2-chloropyrazine act as a monodentate ligand but unfortunately no 1D thiocyanato network was obtained. The present compound consists of 2D coordination networks, which in contrast to the 1D networks are very rare. However, because of the topology of the coordination network no SCM behavior can be expected. The 2D compound <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> shows only antiferromagnetic ordering but further investigations proves that this compound is always contaminated with small amounts of a paramagnetic phase that presumably consist of the precursor. In contrast, <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> shows a metamagnetic transition with a very high critical field of 47<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Surprisingly no saturation is observed, even at the highest fields that were accessible. The reason for the formation of layers instead of chains is still unclear because most other monodentate ligands investigated in our group exhibits the desired topology of the thiocyanato networks and shows SCM behavior. However, this will be the subject of further investigations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In the present contribution investigations on the synthesis and the magnetic properties of new coordination polymers based on iron and cobalt thiocyanato coordination compounds with 2-chloropyrazine as neutral co-ligand were presented. The motivation for this work can be traced back to previous investigations, in which 1D thiocyanato coordination polymers with monodentate co-ligands of composition M(NCX)2(L)2 (M=Fe, Co; X=S, Se; L=monodentate N-donor co-ligand) were prepared that shows a slow relaxation of the magnetization. The present investigations have shown that compounds of these composition cannot be prepared phase pure from solution but are accessible by thermal decomposition of suitable precursor compounds. As expected, 2-chloropyrazine act as a monodentate ligand but unfortunately no 1D thiocyanato network was obtained. The present compound consists of 2D coordination networks, which in contrast to the 1D networks are very rare. However, because of the topology of the coordination network no SCM behavior can be expected. The 2D compound 3-Fe shows only antiferromagnetic ordering but further investigations proves that this compound is always contaminated with small amounts of a paramagnetic phase that presumably consist of the precursor. In contrast, 3-Co shows a metamagnetic transition with a very high critical field of 47kOe at 2K. Surprisingly no saturation is observed, even at the highest fields that were accessible. The reason for the formation of layers instead of chains is still unclear because most other monodentate ligands investigated in our group exhibits the desired topology of the thiocyanato networks and shows SCM behavior. However, this will be the subject of further investigations.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st045">Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">FeSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, KNCS, Co(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and 2-chloropyrazine were obtained from Alfa Aesar and were used without further purification. The crystalline materials that were obtained were filtered off, washed with water and diethyl ether and dried in vacuum. Their purity was checked by XRPD and elemental analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

FeSO4⋅7H2O, KNCS, Co(NCS)2 and 2-chloropyrazine were obtained from Alfa Aesar and were used without further purification. The crystalline materials that were obtained were filtered off, washed with water and diethyl ether and dried in vacuum. Their purity was checked by XRPD and elemental analysis.

elements.clean_text:
Elemental analysis

CHNS analysis was performed using an EURO EA elemental analyzer, fabricates by EURO VECTOR Instruments and Software.

Spectroscopy

All IR data were obtained using an ATI Mattson Genesis Series FTIR Spectrometer, control software: WINFIRST, from ATI Mattson.

X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD)

The measurements were performed using (1) a PANalytical X'Pert Pro MPD Reflection Powder Diffraction System with Cu Kα radiation (λ =154.0598pm) equipped with a PIXcel semiconductor detector from PANanlytical and (2) a Stoe Transmission Powder Diffraction System (STADI P) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =154.0598pm) that is equipped with a linear position-sensitive detector from STOE & CIE.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st095">Differential thermal analysis and thermogravimetry (DTA-TG)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0160" view="all">The thermal decomposition reactions were performed in nitrogen atmosphere (purity: 5.0) in Al<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> crucibles using a STA-409CD thermobalance from Netzsch. The instrument was calibrated using standard references materials. All measurements were performed with a heating rate of 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and a low rate of 75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Differential thermal analysis and thermogravimetry (DTA-TG)

The thermal decomposition reactions were performed in nitrogen atmosphere (purity: 5.0) in Al2O3 crucibles using a STA-409CD thermobalance from Netzsch. The instrument was calibrated using standard references materials. All measurements were performed with a heating rate of 4Kmin-1 and a low rate of 75mLmin-1.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st100">Magnetic measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0165" view="all">All magnetic measurements were performed using a PPMS (Physical Property Measurement System) from Quantum Design, which was equipped with a 9 Telsa magnet. The data were corrected for core diamagnetism.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic measurements

All magnetic measurements were performed using a PPMS (Physical Property Measurement System) from Quantum Design, which was equipped with a 9 Telsa magnet. The data were corrected for core diamagnetism.

The structures were solved with direct methods using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-97 and structure refinements were performed against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>

The crystals of <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> were extremely small and of poor crystallinity. Therefore, diffraction data can only be measured to 2-Theta<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>45° and all reliability factors are relatively high. <ce:inf loc="post">eq</ce:inf>(C) using a riding model. Details of the structure determination are given in

elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal structure analysis

Single-crystal data collections were carried out on an imaging plate diffraction system IPDS-1 for 2-Fe as well as IPDS-2 for 1-Fe, 1-Co and 3-Co from Stoe & CIE using MoKα radiation. The structures were solved with direct methods using shelxs-97 and structure refinements were performed against F 2 using shelxl-97 . Numerical absorption correction was applied using X-RED and X-SHAPE of the program package X-Area . The crystals of 3-Co were extremely small and of poor crystallinity. Therefore, diffraction data can only be measured to 2-Theta=45° and all reliability factors are relatively high. All non hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometry and were refined isotropic with U iso(H)=-1.2 U eq(C) using a riding model. Details of the structure determination are given in  .

cln_elements.clean_text:
To verify the nature of the intermediates additional TG experiments were performed and stopped after the first heating step. The residues obtained were investigated by IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Elemental analysis yields a composition of M(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2 with M=Fe (3-Fe) and M=Co (3-Co) and IR spectroscopic investigations indicates the presence of μ-1,3-bridging thiocyanato anions, because values for ν as(CN) of 2095cm-1 (3-Fe) and 2105cm-1 (3-Co) are observed (see ) . However, comparison of the experimental XRPD patterns of these intermediates with that calculated for 3-Co from single crystal data prove that both compounds are isotypic and are obtained as single crystalline phases ( ). The lattice parameters for 3-Fe were additionally determined from the X-ray powder data to give a =10.7168 (5)Å, b =9.5022 (5)Å, c =15.7235 (8)Å, β =97.407 (2)° and V =1787.8 (2)Å3.

Preparation of Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (1-Fe)

Single crystal suitable for X-ray structure determination were obtained by the reaction of FeSO4⋅7H2O (41.7mg, 0.15mmol), KNCS (29.1mg, 0.3mmol) and 2-chloropyrazine (132μL, 1.5mmol) in 1mL water in a closed snap cap vial. Brown colored block-shaped single-crystals were obtained after one day at room-temperature. Yield based on FeSO4⋅7H2O: 931mg (98.6%). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C18H12FeN10Cl4S2 (630.15): C, 34.31; H, 1.92; N, 22.23; S, 10.18. Found: C, 34.56; H, 2.01; N, 22.16; S, 10.35%. IR (ATR): ν max =2045 (s), 1573 (m), 1514 (m), 1453 (m), 1379 (m), 1288 (m), 1203 (m), 1170 (w), 1136 (s), 1058 (s), 1017 (s), 972 (w), 844 (s), 768 (m), 734 (m), 636 (m), 499 (m), 486 (m), 413 (s) cm-1 ().

Preparation of Co(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4 (1-Co)

Single crystal suitable for X-ray structure determination were obtained by the reaction of Co(NCS)2 (26.1mg, 0.15mmol), 2-chloropyrazine (26.4μL, 0.3mmol) and 1mL water in a closed snap cap vial. Dark red colored block-shaped single-crystals were obtained after one day at room-temperature. Yield based on Co(NCS)2: 852.01mg (89.7%). Elemental Anal. Calc. for C18H12CoN10Cl4S2 (633.23): C, 34.14; H, 1.91; N, 22.12; S, 10.13. Found: C, 33.99; H, 1.88; N, 22.27; S, 10.30%. IR (ATR): ν max =2058 (s), 1579 (w), 1516 (w), 1453 (m), 1379 (s), 1288 (w), 1205 (w), 1170 (w), 1136 (s), 1060 (s), 1019 (s), 969 (w), 844 (s), 827 (m), 769 (s), 732 (m), 639 (w), 499 (s), 415 (s) cm-1 (Figure S2 in the Supplementary material).

Preparation of Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)4⋅2-chloropyrazine solvate (2-Fe)

A few single crystal suitable for X-ray structure determination were obtained by the reaction of FeSO4⋅7H2O (13.9mg, 0.05mmol), KNCS (9.7mg, 0.1mmol) and 2-chloropyrazine (264μL, 3.0mmol) in a closed snap cap vial. On careful inspection of this batch it is obvious that it is contaminated with crystals of 1-Fe.

Preparation of [Co(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2] n  (3-Co)

Red single crystal suitable for X-ray structure determination were obtained by a reaction of Co(NCS)2 (26.1mg, 0.15mmol) 2-chloropyrazine (26.4μL, 0.3mmol) and 1mL acetonitrile in a closed snap cap vial after two month. This compound is always contaminated with small amounts of 1-Co. Larger and phase pure amounts can only be prepared by thermal decomposition (see below).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st025">Thermoanalytical investigations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">As mentioned above compound <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> can be synthesized phase-pure in solution whereas compound <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> with a bridging coordination is not available directly from solution as phase pure compound and in larger amounts. Moreover from all investigations presented above there is no indication that a compound of composition [Fe(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-chloropyrazine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> exists. Therefore, the precursors <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> were investigated for their thermal properties using simultaneous DTA-TG measurements (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). On heating two mass steps are observed in the TG curve of each compound, which are accompanied with endothermic events in the DTA curve. The experimental mass loss of Δ<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">exp</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>34.6% in the first and Δ<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">exp</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>34.5% in the second step for <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and Δ<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">exp</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>35.7% in the first and Δ<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">exp</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>34.4% in the second step for <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> are good agreement with the loss of two 2-chloropyrazine ligands in each step (Δ<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−36.4% for <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and −36.2% for <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold>). On further heating the remaining metal(II) thiocyanates decompose.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st030">Magnetic investigations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">To investigated the magnetic properties of compound <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> their temperature dependence of the susceptibility was measured applying a magnetic field of <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">DC</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe in the temperature range of 300–2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. For compounds <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold>, which consists of discrete complexes only Curie–Weiss paramagnetic behavior is observed. Fitting their magnetic data according to the Curie–Weiss law yields to a Weiss constant of <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−0.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−4.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold>, which are practically zero. Moreover, because of the strong spin orbit coupling of Co(II) cations these values are in any case overestimated. However, the effective magnetic moment of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> for <ce:bold>1-Fe</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> for <ce:bold>1-Co</ce:bold> are slightly higher than the expected value of 4.89<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2) and 3.87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> for Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor> and ).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Similar investigations for <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> with μ-1,3-bridging thiocyanato anions at <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">DC</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 kOe shows an antiferromagnetic ordering at <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>28.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>) and from the √8<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve it is obvious that antiferromagnetic interactions are involved (<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>=</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−31.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K; see ).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The effective magnetic moment obtained from the √8<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve at room-temperature amount to <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, which is in agreement with the expected value for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2). To exclude metamagnetic behavior the magnetization was measured as function of field, which shows only a linear increase of the magnetization typical for antiferromagnetic behavior (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Magnetic measurements for <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> at <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">DC</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 kOe also prove antiferromagnetic ordering at <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">N</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and from the √8<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve it is obvious that antiferromagnetic interactions are involved (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Fitting the magnetic data according to the Curie–Weiss law reveal a strong negative Weiss constant of <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−23.98<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which might be shifted to the negativer side because of strong spin–orbit coupling. The effective magnetic moment of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> obtained from the √8<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve at room-temperature is also slightly higher than the expected value for Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2) (: inset). The reasons for this fact are the large magnetic anisotropy of Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and their spin–orbit coupling, which is frequently observed in cobalt(II) compounds. To investigated if a metamagnetic transition is present an initial curve at <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K up 0–90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe was measured. From the first derivative d<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>/d<ce:italic>H</ce:italic> versus H the critical field <ce:italic>H</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">C</ce:inf> was determined to be 47<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe, which represents the transition point from the antiferromagnetic to the saturated paramagnetic phase (). To investigate this behavior in more detail a saturation magnetization experiment at <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in the range of ±90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe was performed which shows a sigmoidal shape typical for metamagnetic behavior with practically no hysteresis and no saturation (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st035">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">In the present contribution investigations on the synthesis and the magnetic properties of new coordination polymers based on iron and cobalt thiocyanato coordination compounds with 2-chloropyrazine as neutral co-ligand were presented. The motivation for this work can be traced back to previous investigations, in which 1D thiocyanato coordination polymers with monodentate co-ligands of composition M(NCX)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Fe, Co; X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>S, Se; L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>monodentate N-donor co-ligand) were prepared that shows a slow relaxation of the magnetization. The present investigations have shown that compounds of these composition cannot be prepared phase pure from solution but are accessible by thermal decomposition of suitable precursor compounds. As expected, 2-chloropyrazine act as a monodentate ligand but unfortunately no 1D thiocyanato network was obtained. The present compound consists of 2D coordination networks, which in contrast to the 1D networks are very rare. However, because of the topology of the coordination network no SCM behavior can be expected. The 2D compound <ce:bold>3-Fe</ce:bold> shows only antiferromagnetic ordering but further investigations proves that this compound is always contaminated with small amounts of a paramagnetic phase that presumably consist of the precursor. In contrast, <ce:bold>3-Co</ce:bold> shows a metamagnetic transition with a very high critical field of 47<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Surprisingly no saturation is observed, even at the highest fields that were accessible. The reason for the formation of layers instead of chains is still unclear because most other monodentate ligands investigated in our group exhibits the desired topology of the thiocyanato networks and shows SCM behavior. However, this will be the subject of further investigations.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermoanalytical investigations

As mentioned above compound 1-Fe and 1-Co can be synthesized phase-pure in solution whereas compound 3-Co with a bridging coordination is not available directly from solution as phase pure compound and in larger amounts. Moreover from all investigations presented above there is no indication that a compound of composition [Fe(NCS)2(2-chloropyrazine)2] n  exists. Therefore, the precursors 1-Fe and 1-Co were investigated for their thermal properties using simultaneous DTA-TG measurements ( ). On heating two mass steps are observed in the TG curve of each compound, which are accompanied with endothermic events in the DTA curve. The experimental mass loss of Δm exp =34.6% in the first and Δm exp =34.5% in the second step for 1-Fe and Δm exp =35.7% in the first and Δm exp =34.4% in the second step for 1-Co are good agreement with the loss of two 2-chloropyrazine ligands in each step (Δm calc =-36.4% for 1-Fe and -36.2% for 1-Co). On further heating the remaining metal(II) thiocyanates decompose.

Magnetic investigations

To investigated the magnetic properties of compound 1-Fe, 1-Co, 3-Fe and 3-Co their temperature dependence of the susceptibility was measured applying a magnetic field of H DC =1kOe in the temperature range of 300-2K. For compounds 1-Fe and 1-Co, which consists of discrete complexes only Curie-Weiss paramagnetic behavior is observed. Fitting their magnetic data according to the Curie-Weiss law yields to a Weiss constant of θ =-0.45K for 1-Fe and θ =-4.14K for 1-Co, which are practically zero. Moreover, because of the strong spin orbit coupling of Co(II) cations these values are in any case overestimated. However, the effective magnetic moment of μ eff =5.21μB for 1-Fe and μ eff =5.11μB for 1-Co are slightly higher than the expected value of 4.89μB for Fe2+ (S =2, g =2) and 3.87μB for Co2+ (S =3/2, g =2) (  and ).

Similar investigations for 3-Fe with μ-1,3-bridging thiocyanato anions at H DC =1 kOe shows an antiferromagnetic ordering at T N =28.9K ( ) and from the √8χ M T curve it is obvious that antiferromagnetic interactions are involved (θ  = -31.3K; see ).

The effective magnetic moment obtained from the √8χ M T versus T curve at room-temperature amount to μ eff =5.14μB, which is in agreement with the expected value for Fe2+ (S =2, g =2). To exclude metamagnetic behavior the magnetization was measured as function of field, which shows only a linear increase of the magnetization typical for antiferromagnetic behavior ( ).

Magnetic measurements for 3-Co at H DC =1 kOe also prove antiferromagnetic ordering at T N =9.8K and from the √8χ M T versus T curve it is obvious that antiferromagnetic interactions are involved ( ).

Fitting the magnetic data according to the Curie-Weiss law reveal a strong negative Weiss constant of θ =-23.98K, which might be shifted to the negativer side because of strong spin-orbit coupling. The effective magnetic moment of μ eff =5.04μB obtained from the √8χ M T versus T curve at room-temperature is also slightly higher than the expected value for Co2+ (S =3/2, g =2) (: inset). The reasons for this fact are the large magnetic anisotropy of Co2+ and their spin-orbit coupling, which is frequently observed in cobalt(II) compounds. To investigated if a metamagnetic transition is present an initial curve at T =2K up 0-90kOe was measured. From the first derivative dM/dH versus H the critical field H C was determined to be 47kOe, which represents the transition point from the antiferromagnetic to the saturated paramagnetic phase (). To investigate this behavior in more detail a saturation magnetization experiment at T =2K in the range of ±90kOe was performed which shows a sigmoidal shape typical for metamagnetic behavior with practically no hysteresis and no saturation ( ).

Conclusion

In the present contribution investigations on the synthesis and the magnetic properties of new coordination polymers based on iron and cobalt thiocyanato coordination compounds with 2-chloropyrazine as neutral co-ligand were presented. The motivation for this work can be traced back to previous investigations, in which 1D thiocyanato coordination polymers with monodentate co-ligands of composition M(NCX)2(L)2 (M=Fe, Co; X=S, Se; L=monodentate N-donor co-ligand) were prepared that shows a slow relaxation of the magnetization. The present investigations have shown that compounds of these composition cannot be prepared phase pure from solution but are accessible by thermal decomposition of suitable precursor compounds. As expected, 2-chloropyrazine act as a monodentate ligand but unfortunately no 1D thiocyanato network was obtained. The present compound consists of 2D coordination networks, which in contrast to the 1D networks are very rare. However, because of the topology of the coordination network no SCM behavior can be expected. The 2D compound 3-Fe shows only antiferromagnetic ordering but further investigations proves that this compound is always contaminated with small amounts of a paramagnetic phase that presumably consist of the precursor. In contrast, 3-Co shows a metamagnetic transition with a very high critical field of 47kOe at 2K. Surprisingly no saturation is observed, even at the highest fields that were accessible. The reason for the formation of layers instead of chains is still unclear because most other monodentate ligands investigated in our group exhibits the desired topology of the thiocyanato networks and shows SCM behavior. However, this will be the subject of further investigations.
